inline_content.Text: Ideas for software

title: web service to build a sitemap
Build a web service that builds google sitemaps (
https://support.google.com/webmasters/answer/183668?hl=en&ref_topic=4581190
a
https://support.google.com/webmasters/answer/183668?hl=en&ref_topic=4581190
). It crawls the website and builds .xml or .txt file with links, describes how to submit it to google etc. It should use chrome headless.

inline_content.Text: Build a web service that builds google sitemaps (
https://support.google.com/webmasters/answer/183668?hl=en&ref_topic=4581190
). It crawls the website and builds .xml or .txt file with links, describes how to submit it to google etc. It should use chrome headless.

title: It should aggressively cache the results to avoid re-crawling websites. Url should be /tools/build-submit-google-sitemap.html. Maybe use a domain like webtools.io/build-submit-google-sitemap.html

inline_content.Text: It should aggressively cache the results to avoid re-crawling websites. Url should be /tools/build-submit-google-sitemap.html. Maybe use a domain like webtools.io/build-submit-google-sitemap.html

title: To make money limit web service to N links (100? 256?) and up-sell a $10-$30 windows/mac desktop app build on electron.

inline_content.Text: To make money limit web service to N links (100? 256?) and up-sell a $10-$30 windows/mac desktop app build on electron.
Basically,
https://www.xml-sitemaps.com
but better.
web service to build a sitemap

title: For faster PDF rendering, re-compile it. PDF format is rather complicated, mostly text format. A PDF renderer first has to parse it into in-memory representation and then renders it.

inline_content.Text: For faster PDF rendering, re-compile it. PDF format is rather complicated, mostly text format. A PDF renderer first has to parse it into in-memory representation and then renders it.

title: Imagine a binary format that is designed for fast loading and one-time PDF => binary format compilation step. With the right format, parsing step could essentially be eliminated.

inline_content.Text: Imagine a binary format that is designed for fast loading and one-time PDF => binary format compilation step. With the right format, parsing step could essentially be eliminated.

title: We could even improve rendering time with some additional optimizations.

inline_content.Text: We could even improve rendering time with some additional optimizations.

title: For example, there are PDF documents with gigantic images (think 4000 x 4000 pixels) that could be resized to some reasonable value and saved in a format that is fastest to decode.

inline_content.Text: For example, there are PDF documents with gigantic images (think 4000 x 4000 pixels) that could be resized to some reasonable value and saved in a format that is fastest to decode.

title: I’m sure there are optimizations possible for complex vector graphics (e.g. removing stuff that we know will be invisible).

inline_content.Text: I’m sure there are optimizations possible for complex vector graphics (e.g. removing stuff that we know will be invisible).
faster PDF rendering

title: website for comparing poppler vs. mupdf vs. pdfium vs. pdf.js rendering

A website that allows comparing of poppler vs. mupdf vs. pdfium vs pdf.js rendering. Upload a PDF, render each page in each engine in both native size and down-scaled to a reasonably sized thumbnail for overview. The baisc layout would be:

inline_content.Text: A website that allows comparing of poppler vs. mupdf vs. pdfium vs pdf.js rendering. Upload a PDF, render each page in each engine in both native size and down-scaled to a reasonably sized thumbnail for overview. The baisc layout would be:

title: [page 1 mupdf] [page 1 pdfium] [page 1 poppler][page 2 mupdf] [page 2 pdfium] [page 2 poppler] …

inline_content.Text: [page 1 mupdf] [page 1 pdfium] [page 1 poppler][page 2 mupdf] [page 2 pdfium] [page 2 poppler] …

title: Then one could click on the thumbnail to see comparison of the native size.

inline_content.Text: Then one could click on the thumbnail to see comparison of the native size.

title: Bonus feature: some type of overlay comparison.

inline_content.Text: Bonus feature: some type of overlay comparison.
website for comparing poppler vs. mupdf vs. pdfium vs. pdf.js rendering

title: GUI version of
https://github.com/johnkerl/miller
a
https://github.com/johnkerl/miller
(awk, sed, cut, join, and sort for name-indexed data such as CSV, TSV, and tabular JSON)
The weakness of such cmd-line tools is that they require writing of the whole sequence of operations up-front. There are 3 problems with that:

inline_content.Text: The weakness of such cmd-line tools is that they require writing of the whole sequence of operations up-front. There are 3 problems with that:
the syntax is rather arcane

title: the user doesn’t see the data he’s operating on

inline_content.Text: the user doesn’t see the data he’s operating on

title: mistakes are costly i.e. changing the operations has to redo all computation from scratch

inline_content.Text: mistakes are costly i.e. changing the operations has to redo all computation from scratch

title: A better approach is to allow humans multi-step refinements of data in a UI that shows the preview of the operations.

inline_content.Text: A better approach is to allow humans multi-step refinements of data in a UI that shows the preview of the operations.
For example, the operation:

title:
$ mlr --icsv --opprint --barred \
  put '$tiv_delta = $tiv_2012 - $tiv_2011; unset $tiv_2011, $tiv_2012' \
  then sort -nr tiv_delta flins.csv

content_resolved.code:
$ mlr --icsv --opprint --barred \
  put '$tiv_delta = $tiv_2012 - $tiv_2011; unset $tiv_2011, $tiv_2012' \
  then sort -nr tiv_delta flins.csv

title: Would be done as sequence of steps

inline_content.Text: Would be done as sequence of steps

title:
> load flins.csv
$1: 215 records
show first 10 records + headers

> add tiv_delta = $tiv_2012 - $tiv_2011
$2: 215 records
... 10 record preview

> remove tiv_2011 tiv_2012
$3: 215 records
... 10 record preview

> sort by tiv_delta
$4: 215 records
... 10 record preview

> save flins_sorted.csv

content_resolved.code:
> load flins.csv
$1: 215 records
show first 10 records + headers

> add tiv_delta = $tiv_2012 - $tiv_2011
$2: 215 records
... 10 record preview

> remove tiv_2011 tiv_2012
$3: 215 records
... 10 record preview

> sort by tiv_delta
$4: 215 records
... 10 record preview

> save flins_sorted.csv

title: “add”, “remove”, “sort by”, “save” are operations that work on list of records. If argument is not provided, it’s implicitly the last result. The argument can be explicitly provided e.g.:
> $2 save flins_sorted_2.csv
c

inline_content.Text: “add”, “remove”, “sort by”, “save” are operations that work on list of records. If argument is not provided, it’s implicitly the last result. The argument can be explicitly provided e.g.:
> $2 save flins_sorted_2.csv
GUI version of
https://github.com/johnkerl/miller
(awk, sed, cut, join, and sort for name-indexed data such as CSV, TSV, and tabular JSON)

title: GitHub wiki is just a repository. If your project is foo/bar, main repo is github.com/foo/bar.git and wiki repo is
github.com/foo/bar.wiki.git
a
http://github.com/foo/bar.wiki.git

inline_content.Text: GitHub wiki is just a repository. If your project is foo/bar, main repo is github.com/foo/bar.git and wiki repo is
github.com/foo/bar.wiki.git

title: Unclear how to get commit rights. In the worst case scenario could fork the repo and provide instructions for how to manually merge into main repo. Hopefully it’s possible to do from GitHub API.

inline_content.Text: Unclear how to get commit rights. In the worst case scenario could fork the repo and provide instructions for how to manually merge into main repo. Hopefully it’s possible to do from GitHub API.

title: Business model: either charge individuals a little bit per month ($2-$10) for the editor or make public repos free and charge more for privet repos, like $30/month. The idea here is that private repos are used by companies, which can afford to pay more.

inline_content.Text: Business model: either charge individuals a little bit per month ($2-$10) for the editor or make public repos free and charge more for privet repos, like $30/month. The idea here is that private repos are used by companies, which can afford to pay more.

title: Free access for public repos would act as free advertisement.

title: Core insight: Cloud Firestore database has a free usage tier big enough to make hosting a personal blog essentially free. Firebase also provides enough of a backend functionality to implement a blog (authentication, database etc.).

inline_content.Text: Core insight: Cloud Firestore database has a free usage tier big enough to make hosting a personal blog essentially free. Firebase also provides enough of a backend functionality to implement a blog (authentication, database etc.).

title: One could build a single page app that includes all the important functionality of a blog.

inline_content.Text: One could build a single page app that includes all the important functionality of a blog.

title: USP (Unique Selling Proposition) would be: * cheap (almost free) to host * easy to deploy (follow a tutorial custom written for the software) * many themes (write it so that it can use e.g. Hugo or Jekyll themes)

inline_content.Text: USP (Unique Selling Proposition) would be: * cheap (almost free) to host * easy to deploy (follow a tutorial custom written for the software) * many themes (write it so that it can use e.g. Hugo or Jekyll themes)
Written in Vue.

title: Unfortunately, there’s no money in it.

inline_content.Text: Unfortunately, there’s no money in it.
self-hosted blog on
https://firebase.google.com/
